text: I will take the cup of salvation, and call upon the name of the LORD.
text_kjv: I will take the cup of salvation, and call upon the name of the LORD.
text_niv: I will lift up the cup of salvationand call on the name of the Lord.
text_esv: I will lift up the cup of salvation and call on the name of the LORD,
text_nlt: I will lift up the cup of salvationand praise the LORD’s name for saving me.
text_msg: I'll lift high the cup of salvation—a toast to God!I'll pray in the name of God;
text_nasb: I shall lift up the cup of salvation And call upon the name of the LORD.
context: Psalm 116 is a psalm of thanksgiving, likely composed by an individual who has been delivered from a life-threatening situation. The speaker reflects on a profound experience of answered prayer and rescue, prompting a deep sense of gratitude toward God. Historically, psalms of thanksgiving were often recited in the temple as part of a public act of worship. They served as testimonies to God's faithfulness and encouraged others to trust in Him. The imagery used throughout Psalm 116, including references to death, Sheol (the grave), and distress, paints a vivid picture of the psalmist's peril. The 'cup of salvation' in verse 13 is not simply a drinking vessel but rather a symbolic expression alluding to a cup of blessing, associated with celebratory meals and sacrifices offered in the temple to give thanks to God. These meals were often communal and served as a visible sign of God's covenant with His people. The phrase 'call upon the name of the LORD' refers to invoking God's presence and acknowledging His power and sovereignty. In ancient Israel, God's name was considered sacred and held immense power. Calling upon His name was an act of profound reverence and trust, indicating a complete reliance on God's intervention and favor. The psalm's setting likely involved a personal crisis resolved through divine intervention, followed by a public declaration of gratitude within the worshiping community.
meaning: Theologically, Psalm 116:13 encapsulates the essence of a believer's response to God's grace and deliverance. The 'cup of salvation' represents the abundance of God's blessings and the comprehensive nature of His saving work. It symbolizes not merely an escape from physical danger but also deliverance from sin, death, and eternal separation from God. Taking the cup implies an active acceptance of God's gift of salvation and a commitment to live in accordance with His will. It's a conscious decision to embrace the new life offered through faith. The act of 'calling upon the name of the LORD' underscores the importance of prayer and dependence on God. It highlights the believer's acknowledgment that salvation is entirely a work of God's grace, not something earned or deserved. Calling upon God's name is also an act of worship, proclaiming His holiness and sovereignty to both oneself and others. The two actions – taking the cup and calling on the name – are intertwined, representing both the internal reception of grace and the outward expression of faith. This verse also foreshadows the Lord's Supper in the New Testament, where the cup represents the blood of Christ shed for the forgiveness of sins. Christians partake in the cup as a remembrance of Christ's sacrifice and a symbol of their participation in His salvation. The act of calling on the name of the Lord is amplified in the New Testament by the promise that whoever calls on the name of the Lord will be saved (Romans 10:13).
application: Practically, Psalm 116:13 challenges us to actively embrace and celebrate the salvation we have received through Christ. It calls us to move beyond simply acknowledging God's grace to actively participating in it. 'Taking the cup of salvation' in a modern context means consciously accepting the forgiveness, healing, and new life offered through Jesus. It involves surrendering our will to His and allowing Him to transform us from the inside out. This could manifest as a daily commitment to study Scripture, pray, and seek God's guidance in all aspects of our lives. It also means living a life of repentance, confessing our sins and turning away from behaviors that displease God. We are called to be mindful of the price that was paid for our redemption and to live in a way that honors that sacrifice. 'Calling upon the name of the LORD' means cultivating a consistent and vibrant prayer life. It's about turning to God in times of joy, sorrow, need, and thanksgiving. It's about developing a personal relationship with Him through regular communication and seeking His presence in every situation. Furthermore, calling on the name of the Lord can also involve sharing our faith with others and proclaiming the gospel message. It's about being a witness to God's love and grace in our words and actions. We can actively participate in sharing the cup of salvation with others by inviting them to experience the joy and peace that comes from knowing Christ. Are you truly living in the fullness of your salvation? Are you actively pursuing a deeper relationship with God through prayer and obedience? Reflect on specific areas where you can better embrace the 'cup of salvation' and more faithfully 'call upon the name of the LORD' in your daily life. Consider practical steps you can take this week to strengthen your relationship with God and share His love with others.
prayer: Heavenly Father, I come before you with a grateful heart, acknowledging the profound gift of salvation you have offered me through your Son, Jesus Christ. I thank you for your boundless love, mercy, and grace that have rescued me from darkness and brought me into your marvelous light. Help me to truly take the cup of salvation, to fully embrace the new life you have given me, and to live in a way that honors your sacrifice. Lord, teach me to call upon your name in every circumstance, knowing that you are always present, listening, and ready to answer. Fill me with your Holy Spirit, that I may be a faithful witness to your love and share the good news of salvation with those around me. May my life be a reflection of your grace, and may I always give you glory and praise. In Jesus' name, I pray. Amen.

faqs.answer: Taking the cup of salvation symbolizes actively receiving and embracing God's gift of salvation. It's not a passive acceptance, but a conscious decision to accept forgiveness, healing, and new life offered through Christ. It involves surrender, obedience, and a commitment to living in accordance with God's will. It means acknowledging the price Jesus paid and living a life that reflects gratitude for that sacrifice.
faqs.question: Q1 about this verse: What does it mean to 'take the cup of salvation'?

faqs.answer: Calling upon the name of the Lord signifies recognizing God's power, sovereignty, and grace. It demonstrates dependence on God and acknowledging that salvation is a gift, not something earned. It's an act of worship, prayer, and seeking God's intervention. It demonstrates that we trust God to provide for our needs and protect us from harm. The name of the Lord represents His character and authority.
faqs.question: Q2: Why is 'calling upon the name of the LORD' important?

faqs.answer: Psalm 116:13 foreshadows the Lord's Supper, where the cup represents Christ's blood shed for the forgiveness of sins. Partaking in the cup is a remembrance of His sacrifice and a symbol of our participation in His salvation. It’s a tangible way to “take the cup of salvation” and renew our commitment to Christ and His teachings. It reminds us of the covenant established through His blood.
faqs.question: Q3: How does this verse relate to the Lord's Supper?

faqs.answer: In difficult times, remember that the 'cup of salvation' offers hope and deliverance. Actively call upon the name of the Lord in prayer, seeking His strength, guidance, and comfort. Remember His past faithfulness and trust in His ability to bring you through the challenges. Continue to live in obedience to Him, even when it's hard, trusting that He is working all things for your good.
faqs.question: Q4: How can I apply this verse when facing difficult times?

faqs.answer: Practically, you can take the cup of salvation daily by intentionally spending time in prayer and Bible study, seeking God's guidance in your decisions, and actively resisting temptation. Engage in acts of service and kindness towards others, reflecting Christ's love. Confess your sins and seek forgiveness, embracing the grace offered through His sacrifice. Remember your baptism, symbolically taking that cup.
